lncr:titles.lncr:title: Aywas (Litigation guardian of) v. Kirwan, [2010] O.J. No. 2713

lncr:alphanumerictitles.lncr:alphanumerictitle: Aywas (Litigation guardian of) v. Kirwan, [2010] O.J. No. 2713

caseinfo:casename.caseinfo:fullcasename: RE: Wadi Aywas, by his Litigation Guardian Selma Hanna, Selma Hanna, Dina Aywas, Raad Aywas, Rafid Aywas, Dalya Aywas, Lina Aywas, and the minors, Zena Aywas, and Ramey Aywas, by their Litigation Guardian, Selma Hanna, (Plaintiffs), and Debra Kirwan, (Defendant) AND RE: Wadi Aywas, by his Litigation Guardian Selma Hanna, (Applicant), and The Economical Insurance Group, (Respondent)

classify:classitem-identifier.classify:classname: Application by incompetent plaintiff for approval of tort and Statutory Accident Benefits (SABS) settlement allowed in part
Plaintiff was struck by vehicle while walking and suffered neck, back and toe pain
However, severe psychological injuries developed, resulting in catastrophic impairment
$550,000 tort settlement a significant reduction from total assessment of damages, but reasonable given causation issues
$10,000 award for each of two minor children under Family Law Act reasonable
$70,000 sought by spouse under Family Law Act reduced to $40,000 since plaintiff's damages reduced
$400,000 SAB settlement for medical, rehabilitation and attendant care benefits approved.
Application by incompetent plaintiff for approval of Statutory Accident Benefits (SABS) settlement allowed in part
Plaintiff was struck by vehicle while walking and suffered neck, back and toe pain
However, severe psychological injuries developed, resulting in catastrophic impairment
$400,000 SAB settlement for medical, rehabilitation and attendant care benefits approved.
Application by incompetent plaintiff for approval of contingency fees allowed in part
Plaintiff's solicitors obtained $550,000 tort and $400,000 SABs settlement, a good result
Retainer was for 35 per cent of both tort and SABs settlement, which was excessive, given that case was of average complexity and moderate risk
Furthermore, plaintiff entitled to economy for having both cases handled together
25 per cent contingency for tort and 15 per cent contingency for SABs approved.
Application by incompetent plaintiff for approval of tort and Statutory Accident Benefits (SABS) settlement allowed in part
Plaintiff suffered catastrophic injuries after being struck by vehicle
$550,000 tort settlement, $10,000 award for each of two minor children under Family Law Act approved
$70,000 sought by spouse under Family Law Act reduced to $40,000
Plaintiff's spouse was his attorney and entitled to use $300,000 to purchase home in his name near family
Spouse not entitled to have money paid to her in trust but would be paid $2,500 monthly for services.

p.text: Application by the incompetent plaintiff, through his litigation guardian, for approval of the tort and Statutory Accident Benefits (SABS) settlement and contingency fees for his solicitors. The 47-year-old plaintiff was struck by a vehicle while crossing the street. The plaintiff complained of neck, back and toe pain after the accident. However, the plaintiff soon after developed chronic severe headaches, sleep disruption, balance, memory and concentration problems, depression and post-traumatic stress disorder. The plaintiff was unemployable and his injuries qualified as catastrophic impairment. The defendant had agreed to pay $550,000 total for the tort settlement. The plaintiff's two minor children sought $10,000 each and his spouse sought $70,000, under the Family Law Act. The SAB settlement was for $400,000 total for all medical, rehabilitation and attendant care benefits. The plaintiff's spouse, who was also his litigation guardian and attorney pursuant to a power of attorney, requested $300,000 in order to purchase a home next door to the plaintiff's family. The plaintiff's spouse also requested that the settlement monies be paid to her in trust so that she could manage the money and pay herself for her services. The plaintiff had signed a retainer for a 35 per cent contingency of both settlements.
HELD: Application allowed in part.

The tort settlement was a significant reduction from the total assessment of the plaintiff's damages, but was reasonable given the causation issues, and approved. $10,000 was approved for each child under the Family Law Act. The spouse's Family Law Act award was reduced to $40,000 since the plaintiff's damages had been reduced. The spouse's proposal to use $300,000 to purchase the home was approved as it would offer the plaintiff more access to support. However, the home was the plaintiff's, not a matrimonial asset, and was to be registered in his name alone. $24,177 could be used to purchase furniture. The SABs settlement was approved. The spouse's proposal to have the monies paid to her in trust was not acceptable. It was not appropriate for the spouse to determine her own compensation. She would be paid $2,500 per month for her services. The spouse was directed to maintain separate financial accounts for the plaintiff's settlement monies and keep detailed records as she could be asked to pass accounts at any time. While the solicitors obtained a good settlement for the plaintiff, the contingency agreed upon was excessive. The file was of average complexity with a moderate risk to the solicitors. Furthermore, the plaintiff was entitled to economy for having both cases handled together. 15 per cent contingency was approved for the SABs settlement and 25 per cent for the tort settlement. $13,322 disbursements were allowed. Further approval was given to release $13,418 to repay Social Services. Upon receiving further information from the spouse about a TD investment account that allowed for withdrawals and would not encroach upon capital, approval was given for remaining capital to be invested in the recommended account.
Family Law Act, R.S.O. 1990, c. F.3, s. 61
Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 7.08, Rule 74.18, Rule 76.16
Substitute Decisions Act, O. Reg. 100/96, s. 42
Hector H. Emond and Asfrah Syed, for the Plaintiffs.
Hector H. Emond and Asfrah Syed, for the Applicant.

text.inlinenote: [Editor's note: An addendum was released by the Court April 30, 2010; it has been appended to this document.]

p.text: The Court is asked to approve, under section 7.08 of the Rules of Civil Procedure, the settlement of the plaintiff's tort action, as well as his statutory accident benefits (SAB's) settlement, both of which arise out of a motor vehicle accident which occurred in Ottawa on January 4, 2007. The plaintiff is an incapable person. The Court is also required to approve the investment arrangements and the solicitor's contingency fee claimed on both settlements.

All motion materials were ordered to be served on the Office of the Public Guardian and Trustee. I am indebted to Laurie S. Redden, General Counsel to the Public Guardian and Trustee, for her helpful written submissions received by the Court.
Ms. Redden, in her written submission, accurately sets out the role of the Public Guardian and Trustee and the role of plaintiff's counsel in a motion for approval under Rule 7.08, which I adopt.

The role of the Public Guardian and Trustee as described under Rule 7.08(5) is to provide assistance to the Court by way of comment and recommendations, with reasons. Written Reports are provided to the requesting Judge and plaintiff's counsel, based on the facts contained in written materials provided by counsel. The Public Guardian and Trustee does not act as opposing counsel to the Motion. "The approval or absence of objection by the Public Guardian and Trustee is, in and of itself, not approval of the terms of the settlement as contemplated by Rule 7.08(5). It is only one factor among many for the Court to consider." (Adler v. State Farm (2008), 92 O.R. (3d) 266, at para. 29)

The obligation of plaintiff's counsel is to provide the Court with full and frank disclosure of the nature of the claim, damages of the plaintiff, the risks associated with the claim, particulars of the financial retainer, costs recovered, allocation of funds payable to all plaintiffs and costs payable by the plaintiffs, and the management of funds on behalf of the party under disability.

The plaintiff, currently 47 years of age, was a pedestrian crossing at an intersection when hit by the defendant's vehicle. He was taken to hospital by ambulance complaining of neck and back pain and dislocated toe. He was treated and released without being admitted. His post accident course has been very unusual. He has suffered daily severe headaches, sleep disruption, balance problems, reduced memory and concentration, depression, anxiety and post traumatic stress syndrome. For SAB's purposes the plaintiff's injuries have been found to qualify as a catastrophic impairment. He has not been employed since the accident.

Following mediation on January 27, 2010, the tort defendant agreed to pay the sum of $550,000 as an all-inclusive settlement. This amount reflects a significant discount from a full assessment of the plaintiff's damages. The concern of plaintiff's counsel was that at trial there would be a major challenge on the issues of threshold and causation arising from the fact that the plaintiff did not suffer a head injury in what was a relatively minor accident, yet his principal disability is psychiatric in nature and its causal connection to the accident may be seen as tenuous. I agree with plaintiff's counsel's assessment of the risk of proceeding to trial and I consider this settlement to be fair and prudent in the circumstances.

The plaintiff has 7 children, 2 of whom are minors. I approve the section 61 Family Law Act settlements of $10,000 for each of the 2 minor children, which payments will of course be paid into Court pending their respective 18th birthdays.

The plaintiff's counsel suggests that $70,000 from the tort settlement be apportioned to the plaintiff's spouse, Selma Hanna, for her section 61 Family Law Act claim. I would note Selma Hanna is the plaintiff's litigation guardian and is also his attorney under a continuing power of attorney for property given prior to him becoming incapable. I would reduce this proposed award to $40,000. Section 61 F.L.A. damages are derivative and should be reduced in an equitable manner when the tort victim's damages are also reduced.

The plaintiff's guardian wishes to expend the amount of $300,000 from the settlement to buy a house and adjoining property in London, Ontario, near to other family members. The concept is that the plaintiff, his wife and guardian, the minor children and one or more of the adult children would reside in this home. In this environment, the plaintiff would receive the housing and care and security he requires in the supportive environment of this close knit family. After hearing evidence and considering the plaintiff's medical needs (largely supportive supervision which his wife will provide) and cultural factors which are an important aspect of this plan, I approve it.

In an interim endorsement dated March 31, 2010, I authorized the release of the sum of $324,177.23 for the purchase of the London residence and to purchase furnishings. It is important to bear in mind that notwithstanding the planned family usage, this is not a family asset. It is the plaintiff's property. To that end I ordered that title to the property was to be taken in the plaintiff's name alone and the plaintiff's guardian is prohibited from mortgaging, encumbering, transferring or otherwise disposing of the property without seeking Court approval. This restriction should be referenced on title to the property.

The plaintiff's SAB's were also resolved at the January 27, 2010 mediation, for the sum of $400,000 in full and final settlement of all medical, rehabilitation and attendant care benefits. In all the circumstances, I am persuaded that a lump sum settlement in this amount is in the plaintiff's best interests and I approve it.

The plaintiff's guardian proposes that the entire net amount of the SAB's settlement, after paying legal fees, be paid to her to administer in trust for the plaintiff's future care needs, including annual payments to herself as his principal caregiver in an amount she would decide on. The amount of this fund would be several hundred thousand dollars depending on the amount of legal fees allowed on this settlement.

The foregoing proposal is not acceptable. This fund is the property of the plaintiff and is for the purpose of his future care. Therefore, it is not appropriate to pay the plaintiff's guardian and spouse personally this entire fund. An attorney does not have the discretion to benefit herself. I recognize that Ms. Hanna is the person who will be providing on-going supervisor care to the plaintiff and should be compensated in a monthly amount for these services, but the amount must be fixed by the Court. I direct that she be paid $2,500 each month beginning May 1, 2010 from this settlement and subject to revision by further Court order.

Ms. Hanna as guardian is required to maintain a separate bank account for her husband's funds. She is required to keep detailed accounts of all transactions (receipts and disbursements) from that bank account and of any other property belonging to the plaintiff (such as the property recently purchased), in accordance with the requirements of O. Reg. 100/96 under the Substitute Decisions Act and to pass her accounts before the Court pursuant to Rules 74.16 to 74.18, when ordered to do so, or in accordance with section 42 of the Act. I order that the guardian pass her accounts in the Superior Court in London, Ontario within 3 years from the date of this order.

I instruct counsel to investigate and prepare a further submission to the Court on the advisability of placing these future care funds in a tax free structured annuity for the plaintiff's benefit and to also review and advise on available investment funds or vehicles from a chartered bank or major trust company. These funds should be placed, by applicant's counsel, in short term bank investments for the plaintiff's benefit, pending resolution of this issue and further Court order.

The retainer of the plaintiff's counsel is in the form of a contingency fee agreement signed September 14, 2007 by the plaintiff and his spouse Selma Hanna, his litigation guardian and guardian of his property. The retainer agreement provides for a contingency fee of "35% of the settlement funds obtained", both in tort and accident benefits.

A contingency fee agreement in the case of an incapable person is not binding on the Court, but is certainly a matter of importance to be considered as a matter of client expectations, see Giusti v. Scarborough Hospital - Grace Division, [2008] O.J. No. 1899, Re Cogan, [2007] O.J. No. 4539 and Re Cogan, [2010] O.J. No. 827.

I respectively agree with the following statement of Spies J. in Lau v. Bloomfield, [2007] O.J. No. 3200 at paras. 36-37 in which she summarized the information that a Court requires to assess the claim for solicitor's fees:

In order for there to be meaningful court approval, in the motion record counsel must provide a copy of the retainer agreement, the dockets, the hourly rates claimed, a list of the lawyer/law clerks who worked on the file and in the case of lawyers, their year of call and in the case of law clerks, whether they are a junior or senior clerk.

In addition, a summary of the nature of the work done by each person must be included. That summary is not to be simply a list of specific matters that were done, as was provided to me by counsel in this case as this obviously does not give the reviewing judge any assistance whatsoever. Particulars must be provided such as the number of hours spent to prepare an examination, the number of days spent at the examinations and whether it was for the purpose of examining a witness or simply accompanying the client. The same applies to court attendances. To simply state there were motions is meaningless without particulars of the nature of the motion, a summary of the material prepared for the motion and whether it was argued and, if so, the length of the court attendance. This is also obviously the case for mediations and other hearings and settlement conferences. Counsel may also wish to consider reference to some of the factors set out in Rule 57.
It is well established that the factors to be considered when fixing costs to be paid to counsel for a party under a disability are:
The time expended by the solicitor;
The legal complexity of the matters dealt with;
The degree of responsibility assumed by the solicitor;
The monetary value of the matters in issue;
The importance of the matters to the client;
The degree of skill and competence demonstrated by the solicitor;
The results achieved;
The ability of the client to pay;
The client's expectation of the amount of the fee;
The financial risk assumed by the solicitor of pursuing the action, including the risk of non-payment, the likelihood of success and the amount of the expected recovery; and
The social objective of providing access to justice for injured parties. see, Re Solicitor, [1973] 1 O.R. 652 (C.A.)

Ms. Syed deposes that she spent 618.1 hours on these proceedings. She was called to the bar in 2000 and charges an hourly rate of $300. She has also deposed that Mr. Emond spent an additional 102.3 hours on these matters; he was called to the bar in 1982 and charges an hourly rate of $400.

Counsel for the Public Guardian and Trustee submits that a total of 720.4 hours appears excessive in a tort proceeding in which discoveries were not completed and both the tort and SAB's claims were resolved at mediation. I do agree that these hours were at the high end of what might be expected even allowing for what counsel have advised were many complications in pursuing the SAB's claims, relating in particular to the nature of the plaintiff's psychiatric disability.
Fees based on docketed time would be:

I am of the view that the claimed 35% contingency fee on both the tort and the SAB's settlements is excessive. I regard this as a good settlement in a matter of average complexity. The risk assumed by the solicitors was moderate and related mainly to the causation aspects of the plaintiff's injuries. I do not think that applying the same contingency fee to the SAB's settlement as to the tort settlement is generally appropriate, although each case must be considered individually. As Wilkes J. explained in Adler (Litigation guardian of) v. State Farm (2008), 92 O.R. (3d) 266 at paras. 33-38:

[33] Generally speaking, there is not a great deal of legal work required to process and collect all of the benefits to which an injured person is honestly entitled. Some claims for accident benefits may be of such a nature or quality as to require the significant application of time and effort in the adversarial process. In the case at bar, however, Michal Adler's injuries were obvious and serious - his Glasgow Coma scale at the site was at the level of 3. He suffered a traumatic brain injury, a fracture to his pelvis, a fractured femur, a fractured tibia and fibula, a ruptured bladder, an aortic tear, a bilateral pneumothorax/hemothorax, a tracheostomy, he further required the insertion of a G2 tube and the surgical closure of his abdominal wall. In addition, it was the conclusion of Dr. Bernard Schacter that he had sustained a catastrophic injury and would require 24 hour a day care and supervision throughout his lifetime.
[34] As set out above, the file demonstrated actual docketed time of $3,972.50 and the file was in the possession of the present solicitor from June 12, 2007 to settlement on October 15, 2007.

[35] In my view there is a significant difference between a contingency fee requiring Court approval in a tort action in which many complex issues are at stake. Tort actions frequently involve issues of liability and they have the requirement of proof on the balance of probabilities. An accident benefits claim, on the other hand, is very different in nature, particularly when the demonstrable injuries are catastrophic, the needs of the claimant are patent and the wording of the Act, the regulations and the policy are applicable.

[36] In a tort action, the amounts for damages under the various heads of claim allowable, with the exception of general damages for pain, suffering and loss of enjoyment of life, are limited or circumscribed only by the evidence presented to and accepted by the trier of fact. The amounts which the trier of fact in a tort action is prepared to allot to any or all other heads of damage can be significantly impacted upon by the hard work, skill and advocacy of counsel. In an accident benefits claim, the quantum and duration of any allowable head of claim is circumscribed by the Act, the regulations and the policy. A claimant's entitlement to benefits is limited to the wording of the statute, the regulations and the policy. Once established, however, the claimant is entitled to receive those benefits.

[37] In addition to the above, the accident benefits scheme in the Province of Ontario provides for a dispute resolution process designed to minimize costs with the more expensive option of litigation in the Court process only under certain circumstances.

[38] The overall accident benefits scheme is designed to efficiently and effectively pay all allowable, honest claims at minimum cost with a relatively speedy, low cost dispute resolution process. The claims in respect of the application at bar were not the subject of mediation, arbitration or litigation. The file was received by the solicitor with an offer to settle at $1 million. After the solicitor had commissioned some additional reports, a negotiated settlement was reached in the amount of $1,250,000.

I think that another factor to consider is that when handling both a tort and a SAB claim arising from the same motor vehicle accident, there is normally an economy of effort enjoyed by plaintiffs in the context of preparation of the damages claim.

The Court will allow a fee in the amount of 15% of the SAB's lump sum settlement plus the fees of $36,035 previously deducted on the monthly benefits received of $366,604.30. The tort contingency fee is reduced to 25% which fairly compensates the solicitors for the work done.
The disbursements will be allowed as claimed in the sum of $13,322.77, including G.S.T. The trustee is authorized to repay a debt to Social Services in the sum of $13,418.92.
The solicitor's, Emond & Associates are allowed fees in the sum of $220,697.77 (plus the sum of $36,035.00, noted above) calculated as follows:
The Court approves the following payments:
to Selma Hanna, F.L.A.
R.A., F.L.A. into Court
Z.A., F.L.A. into Court
To the plaintiff by his attorney for property, Selma Hanna:
to close purchase of property
to repay Social Services
to purchase furniture

row.entry: Approximate amount to be held by
of a structure or other investment
to be approved by the Court:

p.text: The solicitors are to submit a proposal for structured annuity or other appropriate investment, in writing, as soon as that information is available, the capital of which will be approximately $324,706.08, as noted.
C.T. HACKLAND J.

Upon receipt of further information from the solicitors for Selma Hanna, guardian of the property of Wadi Aywas, I accept the recommendation that the capital sum of approximately $324,000 be invested in a TD Waterhouse investment product, described as a Fidelity Canadian Asset Allocation - T Swipe (Tax Systematic Withdrawal Investment Plan). Unlike an annuity, capital can be withdrawn if required for the benefit of Mr. Aywas from this plan and a monthly payment of $3,000 will be unlikely to significantly deplete the capital, based on the prior performance of this investment vehicle.

The court order will provide that capital withdrawals or monthly payments to Wadi Aywas, by his attorney for property, Selma Hanna will not be permitted without further court order and I will need written confirmation from the investment administrator that it will comply with this restriction.
Further, I approve an additional disbursement account dated April 29, 2010 in the sum of $493.20.
C.T. HACKLAND J.
